(5) (a) Having regard to the history of economic legislation of the State, the sad plight of the agriculturist-debtors in the State and the fact that the agriculturist-debtors are living from hand to mouth and below the subsiste-nce level, the State Legislature was fully justified in enacting the impugned Act. The Act does not take away the propel ty of the purchaser without paying him due compensation. The payment of the purchase money by instalments cannot be taken exception to m view of the poverty of the debto1 and since it is not possible for him to pay the debt in a lump sum ; and as the legislation is for a particular community the provision for payment by instalments can- not be said to work serious injustice to the decree-holder-purchaser. A stranger auction-purchaser has been treated differently because he had nothing to do with the decree and is enjoined to return the property to the agricul- turist-debtor on payment to the purchaser of the entire amount in a lump sum. The object of the Act is thus to protect the poor distressed agriculturist-debtors from the clutches of the greedy creditors who have grabbed the properties of the debtors and deprived them of their main sources of sustenance. Agri- cultural indebtedness is sought to be eradicated and removed in the State by amelioration and improvement of the lot of debtors by bringing them to the subsistenc.e level and reducing their borrowings. The Act does not provide for any drastic or arbitrary procedure in the restoration of the property to the debtor. It cannot be said that the invasion of the rights of the appellants is so excessive as to be branded by the quality of unreasonableness. Thus, all the tests laid down by the Supreme Court for determining the reasonableness of restrictions have been amply fulfilled in this case and there is no consti- tutional infirmity on the ground that the Act is violative of Arti• cle I 9(1)(f). (Paras 32, 35 to 37) (b} It is true that Article 31 confers a guarantoe on the citizen against depri- vation of his property except by authority of law and such law must not only be valid but must also not contravene any of the provisions of Article 19(1)(fJ. In the instant case, the Act is a valid piece oflegislation and amounts to a reason- able restriction and hence the Jaw passes the test of constitutionality. (Para 37) ( c) Under the Statement of Objects and Reasons the main object of the Act is said to be to give relief only to those debtors who had filed suits for recovery of debts after July 14, 1958. Merely because the legislation is com- ptehensive enough to give relief by giving a blanket power to the court to set aside the sales which have been completed even before the passing of the Act, it cannot be contended that the provisions of the Act are in conflict with its objicts and reason. Having regard to the poverty and eco- nomic backwardness of the agriculturist-debtors and the miserable conditions in which they live it cannot be said that if they are treated as a separate cate- gory or class for preferential treatment in public interest then the said classi- fication is unreasonable. In making a classification the legislature cannot be expected to provide abstract symmetry ; but the classes have to be set apart according to the necessities and exigencies of society as dictated by experience and surrounding circumstances. In the present case, the classification rests upon a real and substantial distinction bearing a reasonable and just relation to the thing in respect of which it is made. The pleadings of the appellants do not contain any facts to show how the decree- holder-purchasers and stranger-purchasers are similarly situate. Also having regard to the nature of the rights acquired by the stranger-purchaser and the bona fide alienee it cannot be said that the purchasers at the auction sale are similarly situate or happen to be in exactly the same position so far as the bona fide alienee is concerned. Such a purchaser has a clear notice of the circumstances under which the decree was passed. (1) (a) Article 246(3) of the Constitution provides that subject to clauses (1) and (2) of the Article the legislature of a State has exclusive power to make laws with respect to any of the matters enumerated in List IJ. Entry 30 of List II provides for "money lending and money lenders ; relief to agricultural indebtedness". It is, therefore, quite clear that the Act, which provides for the relief of the indebted agriculturists in the State of Kerala, is within the com- petence of the State legislature. (Para 55 & 56) Fatehchand Himmatlal v. State of Maharashtra, (1977) 2 SCC 670, followed. (b) It is true that Section 20 of the Act provides for the setting aside of any sale of immovable property in which an agriculturist would have had an interest if the property had not been sold in execution of any decree for the recovery of a debt. The section, therefore, deals with a liability which had ceased to subsist on the date when the Act came into force. But it cannot, on that account, be contended, that the law relating to the debt of an agriculturist which has already been paid by the sale of his property in execution of a decree and is therefore not subsisting debt, is beyond the competence of the State legislature. There is nothing in Entry 30 to show that it will not be attracted and would not enable the State legislature to make a law, simply because the debt of the agriculturist had been paid off under a distress sale. The subject-matter of the Entry is 'relief of agricultural indebtedness', and there is no justification for the contention that it is confined only to subsisting indebtedness and would not cover the necessity of providing relief to those agriculturists who had lost their immovable property by court sales in exe- cution of decrees against them. In fact, their problem is more acute and serious for they have lost the wherewithal of their liveJihood and are reduced to a state of penury. An agriculturist does not cease to be one merely because he has 1011 his immovable property and it cannot be said that the State is not interested in providing him necessary relief in such an ~vent. On the other hand, his helrless condition calls for an early solution and it is only natural that the State Legislature should think of rehabilitating him by providing the necessary relief. If the legislature could provide relief to the agriculturists against their subsisting debts by legislation under the Entry there is no reason why it should find itself disabled from doing so in the case of those agricul- turists who had lost their immovable properties in the process of liquidation of their debts by court sales. Their case calls for greater sympathy and speedier relief.
